security_audit.summary: Legitimate dependency management skill. Static findings are false positives: scanner misidentified YAML frontmatter and version documentation as cryptographic algorithms. External commands are documentation examples and scripts use hardcoded package manager operations with no injection vectors.

medium_findings.title: External Command Execution in Documentation
medium_findings.description: Documentation contains 151 instances of shell commands (npm, pip, cargo, etc.) shown as examples. These are documentation only, not executable code. Scripts use hardcoded commands without user input.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: All 151 instances are documentation examples. Script files use hardcoded package manager commands with no user input injection vectors.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded Documentation URLs
low_findings.description: Documentation contains hardcoded URLs to GitHub repositories (taze, npm-check-updates, pip-review). These are reference links, not network requests.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are legitimate documentation links to related tools on GitHub, not executable network requests.

low_findings.title: Tool Existence Checks
low_findings.description: Scripts use command -v to check if tools are installed. Standard practice for prerequisite validation.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: command -v is a safe POSIX command that checks tool existence without executing code or accessing device files.

dangerous_patterns.title: Scanner Misidentification - YAML Frontmatter
dangerous_patterns.description: Static scanner flagged 'Weak cryptographic algorithm' at YAML frontmatter locations (README.md:7, SKILL.md:3, 224, 432, 436). These are actually 'license: MIT' and version conflict resolution JSON snippets, not cryptographic code.
dangerous_patterns.confidence_reasoning: Scanner pattern matched 'MD5' in 'MIT' YAML frontmatter and version numbers. No cryptographic algorithms exist in this skill.

content.value_statement: Managing dependencies across multiple languages is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill automatically detects your project type, applies safe updates while protecting against breaking changes, and runs security audits.
actual_capabilities: Auto-detects project type by scanning for package files (package.json, go.mod, Cargo.toml, etc.)
Applies safe updates automatically (minor and patch versions) while prompting for major versions
Respects intentionally pinned versions by skipping fixed dependencies
Runs security vulnerability audits using ecosystem-specific tools
Diagnoses and resolves common dependency issues like conflicts and version mismatches
limitations: Does not modify code to fix breaking changes from major version upgrades
Requires pre-installed package managers and tools for each language ecosystem
Cannot recover from corrupted node_modules without manual intervention

best_practices: Run dependency updates in a clean git branch and review changes before merging
Always run tests after major updates to verify compatibility
Commit lock files (package-lock.json, yarn.lock, go.sum) alongside dependency changes
anti_patterns: Automatically approving all major version updates without reviewing changelogs
Ignoring security audit results due to low severity
Updating fixed/pinned versions that were intentionally locked

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No. This skill only updates dependency version numbers in package files. It does not modify application code to adapt to breaking changes from major version upgrades.

faq.question: Is it safe to auto-apply minor and patch updates?
faq.answer: Yes. By semantic versioning convention, minor and patch updates are backward compatible. They add features or fix bugs without breaking existing functionality.

faq.question: What happens if a major update breaks my application?
faq.answer: The skill prompts you to approve each major update individually. Review the changelog before approving. If something breaks, you can revert the change in version control.

faq.question: Does this work with monorepos?
faq.answer: Yes. For Node.js projects, the skill supports recursive mode via taze -r. For other languages, run the skill in each subdirectory containing a package file.

faq.question: What security tools does this skill use?
faq.answer: It uses ecosystem-specific tools: npm audit (Node.js), pip-audit and safety (Python), govulncheck (Go), cargo audit (Rust), bundle audit (Ruby), and dotnet list package --vulnerable (.NET).

faq.question: Can I use this offline?
faq.answer: Partial. Checking for outdated packages works offline. Security audits require network access to fetch vulnerability databases. Tool installation requires internet access.
